newsitem.title: HONG KONG: China Unicom held talks with HK Tel -paper.
newsitem.headline: China Unicom held talks with HK Tel -paper.

text.p: China United Telecommunications Corp (China Unicom) said it had held talks with Hong Kong Telecommunications Ltd about the possibility of buying a stake in the locally-listed company, newspapers reported on Thursday.
The Chinese concern had talked with Hongkong Telecom last year but no agreement had been reached, China Unicom president Li Huifen was quoted by the Hongkong Standard as saying.
Unicom hoped to resume the talks, she was quoted as saying.
She said the possibility of future cooperation with HongKong Telecom would not be ruled out, even if the plan to acquire a stake in the company was not successful, the newspaper reported.
The South China Morning Post quoted Li as saying China Unicom was interested in taking a stake in Hongkong Telecom, although she understood the difficulties associated with such a deal.
"This would need to be coodinated by the central (Chinese) government with final approval from the Hong Kong and Macau Affairs Office (of China)," the newspaper quoted Li as saying.
Officials at Hongkong Telecom were not immediately available to comment.
China Unicom is a joint venture of 16 major Chinese organisations, led by the ministries of power, railways and electronics industry.
It was set up in 1994 to compete with the Ministry of Posts and Telecommunications, which previously had a monopoloy in providing telephone services.

On Wednesday, Hongkong Telecom's share price rose HK$0.10 to HK$14.20 on speculation it is seeking a Chinese partner, which is considered positive for the company's future as the British colony reverts to Chinese rule on July 1.

Cable and Wireless Plc, which holds 58.5 percent of Hongkong Telecom, on Wednesday fended off market talks that Chinese interest might take a stake in its Hong Kong unit, saying it would be business as usual through the territory's handover.
